issues.description: The problem statement instructs students to save the updated person by calling personRepository.save(...) with a boolean 'force' flag (e.g., save(person, true).) However, neither the template nor the solution repository exposes such a save(Person, boolean) method on PersonRepository; both repositories use the standard JpaRepository save(Person) signature and the template/solution PersonService implementations call personRepository.save(person) without any boolean parameter. This mismatch will confuse students who look for or try to call a save method with a boolean 'force' parameter (or try to implement it as described), and prevents following the instructions literally.
issues.suggested_fix: Either (A) update the problem statement to reference the actual repository API (i.e., call personRepository.save(person) and return that), removing the mention of a boolean 'force' flag; or (B) if the educational intent is to require a special save(force) semantics, add and document a corresponding save(Person, boolean) method to PersonRepository (and update template and solution accordingly). The simplest fix preserving current code is to amend the problem text to instruct students to call personRepository.save(person) (no boolean).

issues.description: The problem statement instructs students to call personRepository.save(..) with a boolean 'force' flag set to true when persisting parent/child relationships, but both the template and the solution use the standard JpaRepository.save(Person) method (no boolean parameter). This is a semantic API/signature mismatch: the same conceptual operation ('save' to persist a Person) is described with a different method signature in the problem text than what is actually provided in the starter code and reference solution. Students following the problem text may look for or attempt to call a non-existing save(Person, boolean) API, causing confusion and blocking correct implementation.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the problem statement with the actual repository API. Either (A) remove the reference to a boolean 'force' parameter and instruct students to call personRepository.save(person) (matching the template and solution), or (B) if the intent is to require a custom save(Person, boolean) method, update the template and repository API to expose a save(Person, boolean force) method and adjust the solution accordingly. Option A is recommended to avoid adding unnecessary API surface and cognitive load.
